name.text: Reduced Row Echelon Form of a Matrix

questiontext.text:
Write the following matrix in Reduced Row Echelon form.

\(R = {@R@}\)


\(\text{rref}(R) = \)   [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

We need to perform row operations so that the matrix is in reduced row echelon form.
A matrix is in reduced row echelon form if

  • All non-zero rows are above any rows of all zeroes
  • The leading coefficient of a nonzero row is always strictly to the right of the leading coefficient of the row above it
  • The leading coefficient of a nonzero row is \(1\)
  • The leading coefficient is the only non-zero entry in its column.

We are given the matrix,

\( R = {@matrix([1,2,3],[0,2,aa])@} \)


Step 1: It is already the case that the leading coefficient in the first row is \(1\), and that this is the only non-zero entry in the first column.
Therefore, no changes are required to the first column of the matrix.

\( R = {@matrix([1,2,3],[0,2,aa])@} \)


Step 2: We need to make the first non-zero entry in the second row equal to \(1\).
To do this, we'll perform the following row operation,

\( \text{Row(2)} \rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times \text{Row(2)} \)

\( {@matrix([1,2,3],[0,2,aa])@} \rightarrow {@matrix([1,2,3],[0,1,aa/2])@} \)


Step 3: Since the second column now contains a leading \(a\), we must make all the other entries in this column zero. In particular, the second entry in the first row must be zero.

To do this, we'll perform the following row operation,

\( \text{Row(1)} \rightarrow \text{Row(1)} - 2 \times \text{Row(2)} \).

\( {@matrix([1,2,3],[0,1,aa/2])@} \rightarrow {@matrix([1,0,(3-2*(aa/2))],[0,1,aa/2])@} \)


The resulting matrix is in satisfies all of the required condition and is therefore in Reduced Row Echelon Form (RREF).

\( \text{rref}(R) = {@ matrix([1,0,(3-2*(aa/2))],[0,1,aa/2])@} \)
